citation.article-title: Aequorivita gen. nov., a member of the family Flavobacteriaceae isolated from terrestrial and marine Antarctic habitats.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Aequorivita sublithincola sp. nov.
Aequorivita sublithincola (sub.lith.in'co.la. L. pref. sub below; Gr. n. lithos stone; L. nom. n. incola an inhabitant; N.L. n. sublithincola an inhabitant below stone)
The description is the same as that of the genus unless specified otherwise.
Cells appear as rods or filaments in young cultures (0.5-20x0.4-0.5 μm).
Requires sodium ions for growth (at least 1.0% NaCl).
No growth occurs in the presence of 1%ox-bile salts.
Detectable levels of acid are not produced from carbohydrates nor can strains utilize D-glucose as a sole carbon and energy source in the presence of 0.02% yeast extract.
Arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase and ornithine decarboxylase are negative.
Hydrogen sulfide is not formed from L-cysteine.
Produces a strong urease and can hydrolyse Tween 80, gelatin and L-tyrosine (no diffusible pigment).
Unable to hydrolyse starch, aesculin, agar, cellulose, CMC, xylan, dextran, DNA, tributyrin, urate, xanthine, casein or elastin.
Lipase (olive oil) and lecithinase are not produced.
Strains produce N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, but not α-glucosidase, α-galactosidase, α-arabinosidase, β-galactosidase, 6-phospho-bgalactosidase, β-glucosidase, β-glucuronidase or afucosidase.
The G+C content of cells is 36-37 mol%.
The type and only available strain is strain 9-3T (= ACAM 643T=DSM 14238T), which was isolated from a quartz stone sublithic cyanobacterial community found in the Vestfold Hills, Antarctica.
